breakthroughPP.mechanics

Class NetEngine

  • java.lang.Object
    • breakthroughPP.mechanics.Engine
      • breakthroughPP.mechanics.NetEngine
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    Storable, IOTransfer, Setting

    public class NetEngine
extends Engine
    This class provides the functionality to produce a players of different types such as an interactive player and different computer opponents. Those players can locally play on one computer as well as on different computers if the network is appropriate for this purpuse. The last requires the choice between being a guest simply offering a player or being a host which additionally administrates the gameing process. For all possibilies this executable class offers different switches which can be set using command line arguments. Functions to administrate a game are completely inherited from Engine. command line options are: -d Shows the board of the engine and additional information about the state of the game, default is off -s Sets the dimensions of the board, default: 26 26 -m IP|SC|AC|AI IP|SC|AC|AI Sets the types of players: IP: Interactive Player SC: Simple computer player (random moves) AC: advanced computer player AI: artificial intelligent player default: IP IP -b Defines the way of input and output for the Players specified with option "-m" 0: IP: input and output inside the terminal, default SC|AC|AI: no input or output at all, default 1: IP: uses a gui as input and output method SC|AC|AI output in the terminal -w Allowed only with -m SC|AC|AI SC|AC|AI option only. The integer defines the delay time in millisconds which is added to the move to delay an opponent's move, default: 0 ms with -n local: shows both players on one gui with -n offer|receive (): shows a gui of color of the used player -l Load a game, with stored board dimensions and used player types. Allowed in combination "-n" local. There will not be any outputs except the one given by option "-d", meaning terminal in and output only -n offer|receive ()|local Allows playing over network: offer: offer a player at the current computer (guest), this player accepts the board size of the receiving player receive (): search for a player at the optional and run the game (host). If is not specified, the user will be asked to enter it afterwards local: Play locally, default option the player used on the receiving computer or offered is the first argument of "-m" -t Approximate time in s waiting for a partner for "-n receive ": default is 10 s -c In case your are on a linux system you can make the terminal colorful, everywhere else you get an default output, default is off. Georg-August University Goettingen APP breakthroughPP SoSe 2016 Gr CodeSalat
    Author:
    Jan-Philipp Burchert

      • setOptions

        protected void setOptions(java.lang.String[] args)
                   throws java.lang.IllegalArgumentException
        This function can be seen as an addition to Engine.setOptions(String[] args) with regard to the amount of possible switchen a user can set. It processes its input in the same way but collects all the commands, where no matching input token is found. These non matching Arguments are transfered to the Engine.setOptions(String[] args) in case it belongs to one of the old arguments
        Overrides:
        setOptions in class Engine
        Parameters:
        args - comand line arguments
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - in case Engine.setOptions(String[] args) throws one or if for the new options there are either to few or arguments not defined as parameter for this game

      • prepareIOForPlayer

        private void prepareIOForPlayer(int index,
                      int color,
                      Storable store)
        This method creates the specified IOobjects from the chosen options of -b for the Interfaces Requestable and Showable and set them as input and output method respectively. The first player e.g. in -m option uses the specification of the first argument of option -b. The second player alike. The interactive player receive in every case an own gui or text output and input.
        Parameters:
        index - first (0) or second (1) argument of -m or -b option
        color - color of the player
        store - Instance to store, null if storing should be disabled

      • init

        public boolean init()
             throws java.rmi.RemoteException,
                    java.lang.Exception,
                    java.lang.IllegalStateException
        Initilization of game according to the choosen players. Both players do not have access to the board of the (Net)Engine. It expands and uses Engine.init().If the game is played in -n mode the offered player needs to be initilised before starting the game by the computer hosting the game. In case of playing over network, an offered player accepts the conditions of the game provided by the receiveing player. For this reason, offering a player does not include the process of final initilisation of a player because the offered/guest player does not know the size of the board the receiving player wants to play with. The engine of the receiving player needs to complete this initialisation. By initialising the players the players must also initialise there IOmethods with the function Showable.init(Viewer viewer, int color) provided by the interface Showable since the must not have access to the board of the engine and must pocess an own board, where those IO work on. In case of two players playing locally on a single gui, the initiliastion of the player must fullfil the folowing requirement. If the player is initialised with color int 2, the color of the player must be set to red and the its board to two player usage. Color int 0 (RED) and 1 (BLUE) lead to boards o which just the red or the blue player can play on. These requirements are fulfilled in this function and in AbstractPlayer.
        Overrides:
        init in class Engine
        Returns:
        if this instance should control the game true else false
        Throws:
        java.rmi.RemoteException - if remote players cannot be initialised
        java.lang.Exception - if something else fails
        java.lang.IllegalStateException - if Engine.setOptions(String[] args) has not been called and the user's commands have not been considered

      • createTypeOfPlayer

        private AbstractPlayer createTypeOfPlayer(PlayerType type,
                                int color)
                                   throws java.rmi.RemoteException,
                                          java.lang.Exception
        Creates a player by its player type and initializes its color. This includes the initialisation of the board of the player by calling Player.init(int XDim, int YDim, int color). For this purpose the function PlayerFactory.create(IOTransfer inouts, PlayerType playerType, int color) is used.
        Parameters:
        type - type of the player which should be produced
        color - color of the player which should be produced
        Returns:
        an initialised player of the given type and color
        Throws:
        java.rmi.RemoteException - if during initialisation an exception occures (see Player.init(int XDim, int YDim, int color))
        java.lang.Exception - if one occures in Player.init(int XDim, int YDim, int color)

         java.lang.String name)

        Parameters:
        p - Player who should be registered
        name - name of the player to play with

      • find

        private Player find(java.lang.String computername,
          java.lang.String name)
        Search for the player with known name at a computer with a given name.
        Parameters:
        computername - name of the computer where a player is registered
        name - name of the registered player
        Returns:
        a reference to the remote player object or null in case of failure

      • findPartner

        private Player findPartner(java.lang.String computername)
        This function looks up the names of registered remote players at the given computer an connects to the first fitting one. The approximate maximal time this function searches for an offered remote player is specified in maxTime switch. If one partner to play with is found, its reference is returned.
        Parameters:
        computername - name of the computer where a player is registered
        Returns:
        a Player Object or null if no one has been found
